awd_titl_txt: Measurement of Atmospheric He/N2 (Helium to Nitrogen) Ratio as a Tracer of Stratospheric-Tropospheric Exchange
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the development of new instrumentation to measure very precisely the ratio of the concentration of helium (He) to nitrogen (N2) in the atmosphere. Measurements of this ratio will be used to evaluate the exchange of atmospheric constituents between the stratosphere (the layer of the atmosphere just above the troposphere) and the troposphere, the lowest portion of the atmosphere closest to the Earth's surface. Better understanding of stratospheric-tropospheric exchange (STE) is important for increasing general knowledge about the atmosphere and improving models that predict weather and climate.

The newly developed instrumentation will be used to: (1) measure long-term trends in He/N2 as recorded in the Scripps Institute of Oceanography archive of high pressure gas cylinders of air that extends back to the 1970s; (2) conduct real-time measurements of He/N2 for a period spanning one year at La Jolla, where stratospheric influences are expected in association with Santa Anna wind events; and (3) test new methods to allow He/N2 ratios to be measured in flask samples. Modeling studies will be used to assess the expected stratospheric influences on the He/N2 ratio. This project is expected to provide the first estimates of seasonal and synoptic variations in the He/N2 ratio. This effort will also improve the ability of Ar/N2 measurements to serve as a constraint on ocean warming. The new technique will be used to advance the understanding of stratospheric circulation and the resulting implications for tropospheric chemistry, and ultimately, by assessing the sources of these compounds, to attain a better understanding of the effects of human activities on the atmosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to make the first high-precision measurements of the amount of helium in the atmosphere. Helium is present in trace amounts in nearly all natural gas deposits. When natural gas is burned, this helium is released into the atmosphere, thereby increasing the helium abundance in air.  Because helium is naturally present in air in relatively high amounts (at ~5 ppm) the expected changes are small in relative terms.  Detecting these changes required the development of precise methods. 

Our approach was to concentrate the amount of helium being delivered to the mass spectrometer, the instrument used to make the measurement.  We demonstated two concentration methods: the first used a hot titanium sponge to remove all gases except noble gases (which includes helium), and the second used a cryogenic approach, which froze out most of the other gases in air.  We used the first method to show that helium has been increasing steadily in the atmosphere from 1970s to the present using old air samples which have been stored at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. This buildup was shown to be highly consistent with the expected buildup from natural gas burning.

The second method allowed us to make measurements much more rapidly and precisely.  We applied this method to detect changes in ambient helium from minute to minute in the air drawn outside to our laboratory in La Jolla laboratory.  These measurements revealed strong variations in helium that correlated with changes in ambient CO2.  This correlation is consistent with expectations from local natural gas burning, which releases both CO2 and helium. 

Our results and methods have broader implications. Helium measurements may help detect CO2 from natural gas emissions, or help trace rates of mixing in the atmosphere that impact the dispersion of CO2 from fossil-fuels.  Helium is also a potential tracer for stratospheric atmospheric dynamics, because it is enriched in the upper atmosphere, due to its low mass. Finally, helium is a non-renewable resource with high commercial value, particularly the lighter isotope of helium, 3He. Our work showing increases in the more abundant isotope, 4He, indicates that there may be an increase in 3He from an unknown source as well, which would be of major economic and strategic interest. Future work on this interesting problem will help to resolve this mystery.
